metadata.description: A curated list of Points of Interest (POIs) for the unfold.quest project, extracted from a user-provided document.
metadata.source_document_title: Key Surviving Buildings of the Former VEF Factory District in Riga

pois.title: VEF Main Manufacturing Hall
pois.description: Erected in 1899 for the Union company and later part of VEF, this red-brick hall was the primary production space for electrotechnical goods like phones, radios, and cameras. Today, it has been restored and converted into a modern business center, VEF Kvartāls, housing IT firms.

narrative_hooks.history: Originally built in 1899 for the Union company, it became the main production hall for VEF, a leading electrotechnical factory in the interwar period.
narrative_hooks.fun_fact: This hall was where iconic products like 'Perkons' cameras and early telephone exchanges were manufactured.
narrative_hooks.architectural_detail: A large red-brick industrial hall, showcasing late 19th-century factory architecture, now adaptively reused.

practical_info.cost: Free (for exterior viewing, access to some areas may be restricted)

pois.title: VEF Administration Building
pois.description: This neoclassical-styled structure, built in the early 20th century, served as VEF’s corporate headquarters, housing executive offices and design bureaus. After a comprehensive renovation in 2017, it reopened as a boutique office building offering flexible workspaces within the VEF Quarter.

narrative_hooks.history: Once the corporate headquarters of VEF, overseeing the extensive operations of the factory.
narrative_hooks.fun_fact: The building now provides flexible workspaces for startups and creative agencies.
narrative_hooks.architectural_detail: A neoclassical-styled building, indicative of early 20th-century corporate architecture, fully renovated while retaining its historical character.

pois.title: VEF Culture Palace
pois.description: Built from 1951–1960 as a grand workers’ cultural center for VEF personnel, this socialist-realist architectural gem includes a large auditorium, library, and cinema. Following a 2017 renovation, it now operates as Riga’s largest municipal cultural institution, hosting diverse events and the VEF History Museum.

narrative_hooks.history: Constructed during the Soviet era (1951-1960) as a cultural hub for VEF factory workers, it reflected the socialist-realist architectural style.
narrative_hooks.fun_fact: The palace once featured a cinema and library and could seat over 800 attendees in its auditorium.
narrative_hooks.architectural_detail: A prominent example of mid-century socialist-realist architecture, with grand halls and a well-preserved original design.

practical_info.cost: Free (for general access, events/museum may have fees)
practical_info.operating_hours: Varies by events and museum hours

pois.title: VEF Vasarnīca (“Summer House”) Hall
pois.description: Once an internal 'covered street' within the VEF complex used for material transfer and informal worker gatherings, this hall was converted in 2023 into a 600 m² industrial-style event space. With high ceilings and exposed brick, it now hosts concerts, fashion shows, and corporate events as part of VEF Kvartāls.

narrative_hooks.history: Historically served as an internal 'covered street' for material transfer and informal gatherings of VEF workers.
narrative_hooks.fun_fact: Its name, 'Summer House,' alludes to its former informal use as a sheltered gathering place.
narrative_hooks.architectural_detail: A 600 m² industrial-style event space with high ceilings and exposed brick, preserving its industrial past.

pois.title: VEF Workers’ Club / Gym Building
pois.description: Opened in spring 1945, this building was VEF’s on-site workers’ club, offering recreational and social activities like a cinema and library for factory staff. Now repurposed as a public gym, it retains its red-brick façade while serving the Teika neighborhood as a modern fitness facility.

narrative_hooks.history: Built in 1945 as a dedicated workers' club, providing cultural and recreational activities for VEF employees.
narrative_hooks.fun_fact: The building once featured a cinema and library for the factory's staff.
narrative_hooks.architectural_detail: A red-brick building that has been adaptively reused while maintaining its original façade, symbolizing the transformation of industrial welfare facilities.
